results.title: Dressing a Chicken
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description:
Please be advised, this film features footage of dead animals.

Produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, this short instructional film demonstrates the correct method for cleaning and dressing poultry. The film is an interesting historical insight into the changing nature of food production and distribution. It would once have been normal for people to handle a fresh chicken carcass rather than a pre-prepared one from the butcher, and the size of the chicken is considerably smaller than today’s standards.

results.title: A Crop of records
results.brief_description: In 1960, Victoria’s wheat growing record was smashed by a bumper harvest. 95% of the wheat was from varieties bred by the Victorian Department of Agriculture including Pinnacle; Insignia; Beacon; and Olympic. Don Rooney, an agronomist in the Wimmera region talks to Victorian farmer Harry Bouchier about his record harvest. We follow the wheat’s journey from the farm, to the silos and finally being loaded onto cargo ships at the Port of Geelong headed for international destinations.
results.description: In 1960, Victoria’s wheat growing record was smashed by a bumper harvest. 95% of the wheat was from varieties bred by the Victorian Department of Agriculture including Pinnacle; Insignia; Beacon; and Olympic. We follow the wheat’s journey from the farm, to the silos and finally being loaded onto cargo ships at the Port of Geelong headed for international destinations.

We follow the wheat’s journey from the farm, to the silos and finally being loaded onto cargo ships at the Port of Geelong headed for international destinations.

results.title: Canning Vegetables
results.brief_description: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.
results.description: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.

The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.

results.title: Beef Carcase Competition
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: this film contains footage of dead animals.

This film, made by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, was made to promote and highlight the pristine quality beef produced in the Western district of Victoria and Eastern South Australia.

It documents the annual contest to select the best beef carcase; in this instance, held in Portland, Victoria.

results.title: The Argentine ant
results.brief_description: This film describes the methods used by State and Municipal authorities and C.S.I.R.O. to eradicate the Argentine Ant in large suburban and city areas. The efforts of individual householders to eradicate the pest have proved unsuccessful. The film shows, in detail, the large scale methods developed by the C.S.I.R.O. which have been used systematically and methodically in attempting to eradicate the pest.
results.description: This film describes the methods used by State and Municipal authorities and C.S.I.R.O. to eradicate the Argentine Ant in large suburban and city areas. The efforts of individual householders to eradicate the pest have proved unsuccessful. The film shows, in detail, the large scale methods developed by the C.S.I.R.O. which have been used systematically and methodically in attempting to eradicate the pest.

The efforts of individual householders to eradicate the pest have proved unsuccessful. The film shows, in detail, the large scale methods developed by the C.S.I.R.O. which have been used systematically and methodically in attempting to eradicate the pest.

results.title: Songlines in the city. Episode 1
results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Rob Nairn, Fiona Dean, Campbell Manderson, Grant Hansen, Glen Edwards and Peter Lane
results.brief_description:
The Shows Songlines in the City is hosted by two of Melbourne’s Indigenous Musicians, Kutcha Edwards and Grant Hansen, both former members of well known Indigenous rock act Blackfire, and radio stalwarts at local community radio station 3CR.
The three shows have a magazine format with interviews and performances with some of Australia’s leading Aboriginal and non-indigenous artists, including Richard Frankland, Lou Bennet, Andy Alberts, Deniece Hudson, Paul Hester and Nick Barker. All the artists appearing on the show are involved with the Songlines Aboriginal Music Corporation Mentorship Program.
Actors, filmmakers and community members are also profiled. Segments include ‘Kids Talk’ at a local Aboriginal child-care centre, and a chat with koori students involved in an innovative education program
Episode One includes performances by Deniece Hudson with Nick Barker, and Kutcha and Grant with Paul Hester. It also includes the Kids Talk segment, Kate Munroe with the koori news, and interviews.
Community Context
‘Songlines in the City, Episode One’ is one of three half hour shows shot as a pilot for an ongoing indigenous series on Community Television Station Channel 31, Melbourne.
In 2001, SKA TV (a Community Television Production Group) approached Kutcha and Grant with the idea of a local indigenous TV show. SKA applied for and received $2500 from the City of Darebin to assist in the production of the pilots.
Community TV Production Groups RMITV and SKA TV provided in-kind assistance with equipment, facilities and crews, and produced the shows together with Kutcha, Grant, and Fiona Dean.
As a result of this mentoring project, the Aboriginal community received training funding to continue Songlines in the City as an ongoing Victorian koori show in 2002 on Channel 31, Melbourne.

results.title: Cinema
results.brief_description: Sebastian C. Schroeder’s sublime 1973 film ‘Cinema’, takes the physicality of film itself as a site of transformation, as celluloid itself metamorphoses into a magical realm for a group of Afghani children.
results.description: Sebastian C. Schroeder’s sublime 1973 film ‘Cinema’, takes the physicality of film itself as a site of transformation, as celluloid itself metamorphoses into a magical realm for a group of Afghani children.

results.title: Joan Sutherland in concert
results.creator_credit: Brian J Smith, TVW Enterprises, Western Australian Opera Company and Phillip Booth
results.brief_description: Dame Joan Sutherland, “La Stupenda”, accompanied by her husband/arranger and renowned pianist, Richard Bonynge, gives an outstanding performance with a program that is rich and varied from the dramatic to the light-hearted. This full-length recital was recorded at the Perth Concert Hall on 9 March 1982 for television.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian J Smith, TVW Enterprises, Western Australian Opera Company and Phillip Booth

results.title: Gold fever
results.creator_credit: George Cass, TV Ed Productions, Victoria. Schools Division. Curriculum Branch and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: They came to get rich quickly and escape poverty in their homelands, but what they found was not always wealth. This program looks at life on the goldfields and discusses some of the problems that the diggers encountered. Sovereign Hill at Ballarat is featured.

holdings.name: VHS; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: Olaf Ruhen
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Researched and interviewed by James Murdoch, author Olaf Ruhen recalls a life travelling throughout Australia and the South Pacific gathering materials for his books. He speaks of his love of the sea and his affinity with the Tongan people. Ruhen recalls his friendship with the painter, Albert Namatjira. A visit to a writers’ conference in New York inspired Ruhen to create a forum for Australian authors, the Australian Society of Authors.
